Money in software development is in:

  • Good requirements
  • Good implementations

The choice of the programming language is close to irrelevant to fulfill a requirement with a good implementation, i.e., algorithm. A particular language, most importantly, the runtime where the code will, eventually, run in, and its included libraries, might help one get there faster or in a "nicer" way. One might have preferences regarding syntax, paradigma, etc., but all that has little impact on end value. There is, virtually, nothing only one language "does" or one language "doesn't".

Having that in mind, here goes an exploration of basics, similarities and differences of some of the most used languages. Simple to complex examples implemented parallelly on each language to outline its implementation of the intended funcitonalilty. It might also serve as a quick cheatsheet.

Notes:

  • No libraries other than the ones provided by the runtime or the operating system will be used.
  • As a consequence of the previous point, the implementations are not necessarily the common practice.

All source code can be found this GitHub Repository.

If you have any suggestions of languages, features, etc., find any errors or corrections, feel free to create an issue.
